questions.text: A patient presents with a BT Leprosy Lesion on the Face as shown in the image below. Which of the following Nerves is most commonly involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial Nerve

 

Option A: The clinical presentation strongly suggests a case of leprosy, with the facial nerve being the most commonly affected cranial nerve.

 

  • Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which impacts the mucous membranes, cutaneous tissues, and peripheral nerves leading to sensory and motor deficits.

 

Most commonly affected nerves:

 

  • Peripheral nerves - Ulnar > Posterior tibial nerve, median, and lateral popliteal nerves.

  • Cranial nerves: Facial nerve > Trigeminal nerve.

    • Notably, facial skin lesions are associated with a 10-fold increase in the risk of facial nerve involvement in leprosy cases.

    • Facial nerve involvement can lead to facial muscle weakness, paralysis, and loss of facial expressions, which are characteristic features of this condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve:

 

  • The trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve) primarily innervates the face and is responsible for sensations such as touch and pain.

  • While it can be affected in leprosy, it is not the most commonly involved nerve in BT leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve:

 

  • The abducens nerve (sixth cranial nerve) controls the movement of the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.

  • In leprosy, it is less commonly involved compared to the facial nerve, especially in BT leprosy.

 

Option D. Optic nerve:

 

  • The optic nerve (second cranial nerve) is responsible for vision and is not commonly affected in leprosy lesions on the face.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients presenting with leprosy lesions on the face, the most commonly involved nerve is the facial nerve.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 28, Page No 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrisonâ€™s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Page No 1385, 1386, 1388

choices.text: Borderline Tuberculoid is the most common type of Leprosy in India
Borderline Borderline is the most unstable form of Leprosy
Earliest Sign of Leprosy is Loss of Temperature
Facial Nerve is the most common nerve involved in Leprosy

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements regarding leprosy EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Facial Nerve is the most common nerve involved in Leprosy.

 

Option D:

 

  • Ulnar nerve is the most commonly affected nerve in leprosy.
  • Nerve involvement in leprosy:

Ulnar > Posterior tibial > Median > Lateral popliteal > Facial

 

Option A: Borderline Tuberculoid is the most common type of leprosy in India.

 

  • Borderline Tuberculoid presents as a hypopigmented skin lesion with pseudopodia & satellite lesions.

 

 

  • Spectrum of leprosy in India in decreasing order of prevalence.

Borderline Tuberculoid > Borderline Lepromatous > Lepromatous Leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Borderline Borderline is the most unstable form of leprosy:

 

  • Presenting with punched out anesthetic lesions, which have Geographical or Map like appearance.
  • Inverted saucer & punched out lesions are characteristic of Borderline Borderline leprosy.
  • It is rarely seen as it rapidly upgrades towards tuberculoid or downgrades towards lepromatous pole, based on immune status of the individual.

 

 

 

  • Pure Neuritic leprosy (PNL)is not included in the Ridley Jopling classification.
  • Mononeuritis is the most common form of presentation of PNL.
  • Nerve biopsy is the gold standard method for the diagnosis of PNL.

 

Option C.

 

  • Earliest sign of leprosy is loss of temperature, seen over he hands & feet.
  • Sensations lost in the following order:


Temperature > Fine Touch > Pain > Deep Touch or Pressure

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ulnar Nerve is the most affected nerve in Leprosy, not the facial nerve.
  • Early signs of leprosy include Loss of Temperature Sensation, and Borderline Borderline Leprosy is the most immunologically unstable form.

 

Ref: Journal: https://ijdvl.com/current-scenario-of-leprosy-at-tertiary-care-level-hospital-of-rural-central-india/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4318064/, Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine – 19th Edition Page 1124,. Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition Chapter 174 Leprosy, Andrew’s Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology – 12th Edition Page No 336, Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page 28.10 – 28.11

choices.text: No Spontaneous Remission is seen
Half of the cases Resolve Spontaneously After Bacilli Exposure
Spontaneous Remission is more common in Children than in Adults
Indeterminate Leprosy has more Remission than Tuberculoid Leprosy

questions.text: Which among the following is CORRECT regarding the healing of leprosy if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indeterminate Leprosy has more Remission than Tuberculoid Leprosy.

 

Option D:

 

  • Among the given options, Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid is the most appropriate answer
  • The bacillus Mycobacterium leprae is the source of the chronic infectious granulomatous disease known as leprosy (Hansen's disease).

 

Clinically, leprosy can exhibit one or more of the following symptoms

 

  • Patches of hypopigmentation
  • Presence of thickened nerves, and
  • Partial or complete loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas (First sensory modality to be lost is Temperature (hot/cold differentiation).
  • The presence of acid-fast bacilli in nasal smears or the skin.
  • Leprosy symptoms vary depending on how an individual's immune system reacts to the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae.
  • Spontaneous resolution can be seen in about 80–90% (NOT just 50% as given in Option B) of people after being exposed to bacteria.  The remaining patients get clinical leprosy.
  • Indeterminate leprosy typically has hypopigmented, ill-defined lesions. 75 percent of those Indeterminate leprosy patients experience spontaneous remission.
  • Clinically, very few patients exhibit either lepromatous leprosy or tuberculoid leprosy. As a result, compared to patients with tuberculoid leprosy, more patients with indeterminate leprosy experience spontaneous remission. (Choice D)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A:

 

  • Even in the absence of specific treatment, a majority (80-90%) of patients tend to get cured spontaneously.

 

Option C:

 

  • Spontaneous remission in children is variable when compared to adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spontaneous remission occurs even in the absence of specific treatment in majority (almost 80-90%) of the patients, but when compared to adults, in children spontaneous cure is very much variable.
  • If left untreated, Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Page No 28.7

Parks Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine 26th Edition Pg No. 359

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with a normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesion and a history of prolonged fever in childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the absence of thickened nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis

 

Option D:

 

  • The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of Post-Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.
  • Occurs 1-5 years after Kala Azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases.
  • Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented Macules over Trunk and Photosensitivity.
  • The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B
  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.
  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.
  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 33 Page No 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: The Below-Given Image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline Leprosy (BB Leprosy)

 

Option C:

 

  • The given image shows a case of borderline leprosy, or dimorphous leprosy, as evidenced by the inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions on the patient's skin.
  • Inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions can also be seen in Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy (BL).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy

 

  • It is characterized by fewer and more well-demarcated lesions than borderline leprosy, and there is a finding called as Satellite lesions which can be seen in BT leprosy.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy

 

  • It presents with numerous lesions that are more symmetrical and have less sensory loss; it represents one polar end of the leprosy spectrum with a high bacterial load.

 

Option D. Histoid leprosy

 

  • It is a rare form of lepromatous leprosy presenting with firm, nodular lesions that typically do not resemble the "inverted saucer" appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy) and distinguish it from other forms of leprosy.
  • It highlights the importance of recognizing the characteristic "inverted saucer" appearance of the cutaneous lesions and understanding the spectrum of leprosy classifications, which is essential for appropriate diagnosis and management

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 28.3, 28.5, 28.10

choices.text: Superficial Branch of Radial Nerve

questions.text: Which nerve is biopsied for the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial Branch of Radial Nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Superficial branch of radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy.
  • Pure neuritic leprosy is characterized by asymmetrical involvement of peripheral nerve trunks without visible skin lesions.
  • To confirm the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy, nerve biopsy is considered the gold standard. It is essential to biopsy only sensory nerves and avoid motor or major nerve trunks, as well as mixed nerves.
  • For nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy, the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is typically utilized.

 

 

  • The biopsy sample should be taken from a purely sensory thickened peripheral nerve, such as the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist, ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand, or sural nerve near the ankle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic Leprosy, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the preferred site for biopsy due to its accessibility, lower risk of complications, and high diagnostic yield.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page No 28.11 28.14, Sensory reanimation of the hand by transfer of the superficial branch of the radial nerve to the median and ulnar nerve - Scientific Figure on ResearchGate. Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Transfer-of-the-superficial-branch-of-the-radial-nerve-SBRN-to-the-median-nerve-MN_fig5_309138539 [accessed 9 Nov, 2023]

questions.text: A patient presented with Incomplete Closure of Left Eye. On examination Orbicularis Oculi weakness was found, and Cornea shows Decreased Sensation. Which of the following organisms is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium Leprae

 

Option B:

 

  • Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is caused by Mycobacterium leprae.
  • It affects the skin, peripheral and cranial nerves, leading to findings such as Orbicularis Oculi Weakness (Lagophthalmos) and Decreased Corneal Sensation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent of tuberculosis, not typically associated with nerve involvement that would lead to orbicularis oculi weakness or corneal anaesthesia.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium marinum:

 

  • Mycobacterium marinum causes a skin disease known as "aquarium granuloma," which typically does not lead to the neural or ocular symptoms described.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus:

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus is a parasitic worm that causes onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness.
  • It is associated with severe itching, visual impairment and permanent blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae is the causative organism of leprosy (Hansen's disease), which can lead to nerve involvement manifesting as orbicularis oculi weakness and decreased corneal sensation.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 27 Page No 378

questions.text: Match the following Leprosy types in Column A with their clinical features in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option 1. Indeterminate leprosy (IL) (c No Nerve Involvement):

 

  • Indeterminate leprosy is an early form of the disease and often presents with nonspecific skin lesions without definite nerve involvement.

 

Option 2. Lepromatous Leprosy (LL) (a Leonine Facies):

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy is characterized by diffuse infiltration of the skin, which can lead to thickening of the skin and the classic leonine facies (lion-like appearance).

 

Option 3. Borderline Borderline (BB) (b Punched Out Lesions):

 

  • Punched out lesions with well-defined inner border and ill-defined outer border can be seen in BB hansens disease.

 

 

Option 4. Tuberculoid (TT) (d Saucer right way up lesions):

 

  • Tuberculoid leprosy presents with well-demarcated, hypopigmented, and anesthetic skin lesions which have well defined border and the elevated border slopes down to flat centre, which is described as “Saucer right way up” lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical features associated with different types of leprosy: indeterminate leprosy presents without nerve involvement, lepromatous leprosy can present with leonine facies, and tuberculoid leprosy presents with Saucer right way up skin lesions.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 15 Page No 240-245

questions.text: A 38-years-old male presents with multiple hypopigmented and hypo anaesthetic lesions over his body, which are almost symmetrical. Which of the following leprosy is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Borderline Lepromatous

 

Option A:

 

  • In borderline lepromatous leprosy, patients typically present with numerous lesions that are almost symmetrically distributed, as described.

  • This form is between lepromatous and tuberculoid on the spectrum, showing features of both.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Borderline tuberculoid:

 

  • In Borderline tuberculoid leprosy, the number of lesions is fewer and they are non-symmetrical.

  • There may also be a characteristic "satellite lesion" near a larger patch.

 

Option C. Lepromatous:

 

  • Lepromatous Leprosy presents with diffuse, symmetrical skin involvement that includes macules, patches, and nodular lesions.

  • The lesions are more numerous and widespread than in the borderline forms.

  • Also, sensations over lesions are mostly intact in LL, as opposed to mentioned in this clinical vignette.

 

Option D. Tuberculoid:

 

  • Tuberculoid leprosy presents with a single or few well-demarcated, hypopigmented, and anesthetic patches.

  • These lesions have a "saucer-shaped" appearance and represent a strong immune response that limits the number of lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of multiple annular or punched-out lesions with almost symmetrical distribution suggests borderline lepromatous leprosy.

  • This form shows features intermediate between lepromatous and tuberculoid leprosy, with a higher number of lesions than borderline tuberculoid leprosy and less symmetry than lepromatous leprosy.Top of Form

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 15 Page No 244

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy is most seen India?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline Tuberculoid (BT)

 

Option C:

 

  • Borderline tuberculoid leprosy is the most common form of leprosy in India.
  • It typically presents with a few hypopigmented patches with a mildly elevated border and sloping to a flat centre.
  • The presence of a satellite lesion near a larger patch is characteristic of BT leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline Lepromatous (BL):

 

  • Borderline lepromatous leprosy does occur in India, it is not the most common form.
  • It is characterized by multiple hypopigmented patches that tend towards symmetry.

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy (LL):

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy presents with numerous diffuse nodules and plaques and tends to have a symmetric distribution, but it is not the most common type of leprosy in India.

 

Option D. Borderline (BB):

 

  • Borderline (BB) leprosy represents an intermediate form between tuberculoid and lepromatous leprosy and is less common than BT leprosy.
  • It is characterized by punched-out lesions.
  • It is the most unstable form of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Borderline tuberculoid (BT) leprosy is the most common form of leprosy in India, typically presenting with a single or few hypopigmented patches with a characteristic satellite lesion.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 15 Page No 242

choices.text: History of Atopy might be present in the Family
Indeterminate Leprosy is an important differential for this presentation
It is a Variant of Vitiligo

questions.text: A 6-year-old child came with white lesions over his face as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a Variant of Vitiligo

 

Option D:

 

  • Based on the information provided and the appearance of the lesions in the image, the diagnosis is most likely pityriasis alba, which is a common skin disorder seen in children that causes hypopigmented, scaly patches.
  • This statement is incorrect regarding the condition in the image. Pityriasis alba is not a variant of vitiligo.
  • Vitiligo is characterized by the complete absence of melanocytes in the affected area, leading to well-demarcated, White patches (Depigmented lesions), whereas pityriasis alba typically presents with less distinct, more irregular patches that are not completely depigmented.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. History of atopy might be present in the family:

 

  • Pityriasis alba is often associated with a history of atopic dermatitis or other atopic diseases, which may have a familial occurrence.

 

Option B. Mostly happens in children:

 

  • Pityriasis alba predominantly occurs in children and is considered a benign condition that usually resolves with age.

 

Option C. Indeterminate leprosyis an important differential for this presentation:

 

  • When evaluating hypopigmented lesions, especially in areas where leprosy is endemic, it is crucial to consider leprosy in the differential diagnosis.

 

 

 

  • Indeterminate leprosy presents with a single hypopigmented macule and can be a consideration before the disease progresses to more definitive forms.
  • Biopsy is the IOC; Peri-neural, Periappendageal Lymphyocytosis seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis alba is a common cause of hypopigmented lesions in children, which may be confused with other conditions such as vitiligo or indeterminate leprosy.
  • Understanding the clinical presentation and associated conditions, like atopy, is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 39.25, 88.34

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from a Leprosy-Endemic Region presents with Painless Ulcers on the soles of his Feet. He has a history of symmetrically distributed Skin Nodules, and on examination, you notice Thickened Peripheral Nerves. The ulcers have a punched-out appearance with a pale base and undermined edges. Which type of leprosy is most commonly associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepromatous Leprosy (LL)

 

Option B:

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy is characterized by extensive skin lesions and nerve involvement not due to nerve compression but due to invasion of the nerves by the bacilli
  • Nerve invasion occurs in late stages of LL and is seen in peripheral nerves (peripheral neuropathy).

 

 

 

  • Due to widespread nerve involvement, there is development of trophic ulcers, particularly on pressure points like the feet, due to unnoticed injuries.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Borderline Lepromatous (BL) Leprosy

 

  • It is a less severe form than LL and typically presents with less extensive skin lesions and nerve involvement.

 

Option C. Borderline Tuberculoid (BT) Leprosy

 

  • It presents with skin lesions that are fewer in number and more well-demarcated than BL or LL, with more significant nerve involvement leading to anaesthesia.

 

Option D. Borderline (BB) leprosy

 

  • It is an intermediate form and can present with skin lesions that have an "inverted saucer" appearance, but without the extensive nodule formation seen in LL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy (LL) is the type of leprosy that commonly presents with trophic ulcers due to its extensive nerve damage, leading to loss of sensation and unrecognized trauma, particularly in pressure areas like the soles of the feet.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 326

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy is NOT included in Ridley Jopling Classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pure Neuritic Leprosy

 

Option C:

 

  • Pure Neuritic Leprosy is not included in the Ridley-Jopling classification, which classifies leprosy based on the immunological response and only includes forms with cutaneous lesions.
  • Indeterminate leprosy is also NOT included in this classification system.
  • Ridley-Jopling Classification includes:
    • Tuberculoid Leprosy 
    • Borderline Tuberculoid
    • Borderline Borderline
    • Borderline Lepromatous
    • Lepromatous Leprosy 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline Lepromatous (BL):

 

  • Borderline lepromatous is a part of the Ridley-Jopling classification of leprosy.
  • It represents an immunological form of leprosy that falls between lepromatous and tuberculoid leprosy on the spectrum.

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy (LL):

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy is one end of the spectrum in the Ridley-Jopling classification, characterized by a large number of bacilli and diffuse lesions.

 

Option D. Borderline (BB):

 

  • Borderline (BB) leprosy, also known as mid-borderline or borderline-borderline leprosy, is included in the Ridley-Jopling classification and represents an intermediate form between BL and BT leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pure Neuritic Leprosy is not part of the Ridley-Jopling classification of leprosy, as this classification system is based on the spectrum of disease with cutaneous lesions and immunological response, whereas Pure Neuritic Leprosy presents only with nerve involvement without the skin lesions typically seen in leprosy.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 8, 9

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from Bihar presents with a 9 Month History of an Ill-Defined, Hypopigmented Slightly Atrophic Patch on the face as shown in the image below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indeterminate Leprosy

 

Option B:

 

  • Indeterminate leprosy presents with a single, hypopigmented, slightly atrophic patch.
  • Sensation can be normal or impaired, and the location of the patient (Bihar, a region endemic to leprosy) supports this diagnosis.
  • Biopsy is the IOC: Peri-neural, Periappendageal Lymphyocytosis seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pityriasis alba:

 

  • Pityriasis alba typically presents as multiple, ill-defined, hypopigmented patches primarily on the face and is often associated with a history of atopy.

 

 

 

  • The lesions are mildly scaly and non-atrophic, and sensation is intact.

 

Option C. Atopic Dermatitis:

 

  • Atopic dermatitis usually presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions, often in flexural areas, not typically as a single hypopigmented atrophic patch.

 

Option D. Niacin Deficiency:

 

  • Niacin deficiency, or pellagra, typically presents with dermatitis in sun-exposed areas, diarrhea, and dementia, not as a single hypopigmented atrophic patch on the face.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose indeterminate leprosy by identifying a single, hypopigmented, slightly atrophic patch on the skin, with possibly impaired sensation, especially in a patient from an endemic area.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 16

questions.text: A 40-years-old male presented with multiple hypopigmented macules on trunk. On examination, the lesions were non-scaly, shiny and hypo aesthetic. Which of the following tests should be performed to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Slit Skin Smear

 

Option C:

 

  • A slit skin smear is performed by taking a sample from the earlobes or lesions and staining for acid-fast bacilli, which is diagnostic for leprosy.
  • It helps to detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae in the skin lesions.

 

This clinical vignette is suggestive a patient with Leprosy

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diascopy:

 

  • Diascopy is used to determine the nature of erythema or lesions by applying pressure with a glass slide.
  • It helps to differentiate erythema from purpura but is not useful for diagnosing hypopigmented, anesthetic lesions in leprosy.

 

Option B. Lepromin Test:

 

  • Lepromin test is not a diagnostic test for leprosy.
  • It is used to determine the type of immune response (cell-mediated immunity) a person has to Mycobacterium leprae and can help classify the form of leprosy and to give estimate of the prognosis of the patients, but does not confirm the presence of the disease itself.

 

Option D. Woods Lamp:

 

  • Woods lamp is used to highlight areas of skin depigmentation, such as in vitiligo or some fungal infections.
  • It is not useful for diagnosing leprosy, as the causative organism does not fluoresce under UV light.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perform a slit skin smear to diagnose leprosy by detecting Mycobacterium leprae in skin lesions, particularly when the clinical presentation includes multiple hypopigmented, non-scaly, shiny, and hypoesthetic macules on the trunk.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition, Page No 278, 299

questions.text: Which of the following sensations should be checked first in a patient suffering from Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hot and Cold Differentiation

 

Explanation:

 

Option C:

 

  • In leprosy, the first sensation to be lost is the ability to differentiate between hot and cold temperatures, which is an early sign of nerve involvement.

 

Sensations lost in the following order:

 

  • Temperature (Hot and Cold differentiation) > Fine Touch > Pain > deep touch or pressure

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In leprosy, the differentiation between hot and cold temperatures is the first sensory modality affected due to nerve involvement.
  • This early clinical sign should be checked first in patients suspected of having leprosy.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 11 Page No 175

IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 28 Page No 442

choices.text: Lepromin Test is Negative as Cell Mediated Immunity is very Low
Facial Nerve involvement may lead to Blindness
Anaesthetic Skin Patches and Tender Nerves Seen

questions.text: All of the following statements are TRUE in relation to Lepromatous Leprosy, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anaesthetic Skin Patches and Tender Nerves Seen

 

Option D:

 

  • In lepromatous leprosy, patients typically have extensive skin lesions with little to no sensation loss (anaesthesia) and the nerves are not usually tender.
  • This is a feature more characteristic of tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patient is infective:

 

  • Patients with lepromatous leprosy are considered infective due to the high bacterial load in their lesions.

 

Option B. Lepromin test is negative as cell mediated immunity is very low:

 

  • The lepromin skin test is typically negative in lepromatous leprosy because of the poor cell-mediated immune response against Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Option C. Facial nerve involvement may lead to Blindness:

 

  • Involvement of the facial nerve can lead to lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids completely), which can result in corneal ulcers and potential blindness if not treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In lepromatous leprosy, the hallmark features include extensive non-tender and non-anesthetic skin lesions due to the high number of bacteria and poor cell-mediated immunity, which also results in a negative lepromin test.
  • Facial nerve involvement can lead to complications such as blindness, but tender nerves are not a feature of this type of leprosy.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 29

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest deformity seen in leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Claw hand

 

Option C. Claw hand:

 

  • Claw hand deformity is the most common deformity seen in leprosy.

 

 

  • It results from ulnar nerve damage, leading to hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ape thumb deformity:

 

  • Ape thumb deformity (also known as simian hand) can occur in leprosy due to thenar muscle atrophy; it is not the most common deformity.

 

Option B. Leonine facies:

 

  • Leonine facies describes the facial appearance often seen in lepromatous leprosy due to infiltrative lesions, not a deformity of the hands or feet.

 

 

Option D. Foot drop:

 

  • Foot drop, resulting from damage to the common peroneal nerve, is a common deformity in leprosy but not as frequent as claw hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Claw hand deformity is the most common deformity seen in leprosy.
  • It results from ulnar nerve damage, a frequent occurrence in leprosy due to the bacillus's affinity for cooler temperatures, where nerves near the skin surface are affected.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 331

choices.text: It infects Skin, Peripheral Nervous System and Upper Respiratory System
It is transmitted via Respiratory Tract
Solid, Fragmented and Granular Bacteria are all viable

questions.text: All of the following statements are true related to Mycobacterium leprae EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Solid, Fragmented and Granular Bacteria are all viable

 

Option D:

 

  • In the context of leprosy, only the solid-staining bacilli are considered viable.
  • Fragmented and granular forms represent non-viable or degenerating bacilli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It infects skin, peripheral nervous system and upper respiratory system:

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae targets the skin, peripheral nerves, and the mucosa of the upper respiratory tract.
  • It can also infect Eyes, Testes, Muscles and Bones.
  • It has a predilection for cooler areas of the body.

 

Option B. It is transmitted via Respiratory tract:

 

  • The most widely accepted mode of transmission for Mycobacterium leprae is via the respiratory route, from nasal and other secretions of patients with untreated, multibacillary leprosy.
  • It can also spread through skin-to-skin contact, via trans placental and through breast milk.

 

Option C. It spares CNS, Uterus:

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae does not typically infect the central nervous system or the uterus, as the organism prefers cooler temperatures than those found in these locations.
  • CVS, GIT, Lungs, Prostate, Major blood vessels are also spared.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In leprosy, only solid-staining bacilli of Mycobacterium leprae are considered viable, whereas fragmented and granular forms are not.
  • Recognizing the viability of bacterial forms is essential for understanding the infectiousness and treatment response of leprosy.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 9 Page No 147

choices.text: Saucer Right Way up Lesions
Christmas Tree Appearance of Lesions
Dew Drop on Rose Petal Appearance of Lesions

questions.text: Which of the following options is the classical descriptive term used for the lesions of Borderline Leprosy and also Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inverted Saucer Shaped Lesions

 

Option B:

 

  • Borderline Leprosy (BB) and Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy (BL) are often described as having "Inverted Saucer Shaped Lesions."

 

 

  • This term describes the morphology where the inner border of the lesion is perpendicular and outer margins are sloping, giving an appearance of an inverted saucer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Saucer right way up lesions:

 

  • "Saucer right way up lesions" are seen in Tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Option C. Christmas tree appearance of lesions:

 

  • The "Christmas tree" appearance is not typically used to describe leprosy lesions but is more commonly associated with other dermatological conditions like pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D. Dew drop on rose petal appearance of lesions:

 

  • This description is characteristically used for the vesicles seen in varicella (chickenpox), not leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "inverted saucer shaped lesions" is a descriptive term used for the lesions of Borderline (BB) and Borderline Lepromatous (BL) Leprosy, indicative of the specific morphological appearance of these lesions in the disease spectrum.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 21, 25
